arch:property.oc:show_val: This is a cobble wall found over a week ago and left pedastelled until we found out if these cobbles are associated with the ones in the eastern half of the trench. This locus was extended when we found additional cobbles extending the second course of stones to the south baulk. So this locus is the removal locus for the wall, the fill above the extention of the second course of the wall and the second course stones (about 1m long) that were left in situ. The wall itself was 2 courses and 1 row but was probably wider judging from the continuation of the bottom course which was about 4 rows wide.
dry and brittle topsoil/subtopsoil poorly sorted silt
The soil is brittle and dry but gets continually softer and more moist as you descend down.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: a few large cobbles at up to .4m and mostly smaller cobbles .10-.07m in size
none-some mixed areas with cobbles and pottery, nothing definite
cobble area, 2m away almost the same elevation as top course
there are a few stones that are unrelated to the wall, possible collapse from the wall
